name: pyxem 0.14.2
body:
pyxem is open source software focussed on the analysis of multi-dimensional diffraction signals. This patch release contains a small number of bugfixes as well as bringing some of pyxem's dependencies up to date. This is the version that will be used at the workshop: **Electron diffraction for solving engineering problems** ([webpage](https://www.esteem3.eu/news?backRef=86&news=Electron_diffraction_for_solving_engineering_problems_Department_of_Physics_NTNU)). Updating from `0.14.0` and `0.14.1` is encouraged as the changes introduced in `0.14.2` are non-breaking.

For full details please see the [changelog](https://github.com/pyxem/pyxem/blob/master/CHANGELOG.rst).

name: pyxem 0.14.1
body: pyxem is open source software focussed on the analysis of multi-dimensional diffraction signals. This version is functionally equivalent to `0.14.0` but includes a correct file for Zenodo.

name: pyxem 0.14.0
body: pyxem is open source software focussed on the analysis of multi-dimensional diffraction signals. It can be downloaded via pip or conda (suggested). This minor release adds a range of new features and makes some general improvements to the API. For a full list of changes please see the CHANGELOG. Please also be aware that as a minor release of a `0.x` code this release may break existing pipelines.

name: pyxem 0.13.3
body:
pyxem is open source software focussed on the analysis of multi-dimensional diffraction signals. It can be downloaded via pip or conda (suggested).

This patch release continues the improvement of the codes compatibility with hyperspy (#775) and fixes some bugs within the template matching workflow (#771). It contains no breaking changes.

name: pyxem 0.13.2
body:
pyxem is open source software focussed on the analysis of multi-dimensional diffraction signals. It can be downloaded via pip or conda (suggested). 

This patch release makes the code python 3.9 compliant and allows the use of the latest version of hyperspy. Updating to this version should not break existing pipelines, and all users are encouraged to upgrade as soon as possible.

name: pyxem 0.13.1
body: pyxem is open source software focussed on the analysis of multi-dimensional diffraction signals. It can be downloaded via pip or conda (suggested). This patch release corrects a small number of bugs. For a full list of changes please see the CHANGELOG. Updating to this version should **not** break existing pipelines, and all users are encouraged to upgrade as soon as possible.

name: pyxem 0.13.0
body:
pyxem is open source software focussed on the analysis of multi-dimensional diffraction signals. It can be downloaded via pip or conda (suggested). This minor release adds a range of new features and makes some improvements to the clarity of the API. For a full list of changes please see the CHANGELOG. Please be aware that the code remains in active development and updating to this version may break existing pipelines. 

Release Highlights
-------------------------
### 1 - New AcceleratedIndexationGenerator (#673)
This should provide a faster, lazy solution to orientation indexing problems.

### 2 - Phase Retrieval for DPC data (#662)
With three implementation (those of kottler, arnison and frankot) from the literature.

### 3 - Better Lazy Processing
Through a number of contributions, many pyxem functions now work well with lazy data. This include locating and centering the direct beam (#648 and #658) as well as plotting (#655) and many of the methods for Diffraction2D.

### 4 - Simplification of the API
Notably importing now follows a simpler logic c/o #704.

name: pyxem 0.13.0-rc.1
body: This release candidate exists to facilitate the testing of the pyxem-demos

name: pyxem 0.12.3
body:
pyxem is an open-source python library for multi-dimensional diffraction analysis.

This patch allows pyxem to support the most recent developments in `hyperspy` (the 1.6 series) and `skimage` (the 0.17 series).

name: pyxem 0.12.2
body:
pyxem is an open-source python library for multi-dimensional diffraction analysis.

This patch release provides some minor developer improvements, including the addition of a changelog. It is comprised of two merged pull requests: #644 and #645

name: pyxem 0.12.1
body:
pyxem 0.12.1 is an open-source python library for multi-dimensional diffraction analysis.

This patch release packages the `dummy_data` module correctly and pins `hyperspy==1.5.2` to avoid a bug in the `get_histogram` method introduced in `hyperspy-1.6.0`.

name: pyxem 0.12.0
body:
pyxem 0.12.0 is an open-source python library for multi-dimensional diffraction analysis.

In this release we have merged the related package pixSTEM (https://pixstem.org/) into pyxem. This has added functionality for differential phase contrast imaging and provided a number of operations written in `dask` to enable out-of-memory and distributed evaluation.

name: pyxem 0.11.0
body:
pyXem 0.11.0 is the (delayed) Q1 2020 minor release of pyXem, an open-source Python library for crystallographic diffraction.

In this release cycle we have added a significant amount of new functionality to the code, as summarized below. The API for prior functionality from v0.10.x has changed very minimally. Details of all development associated with this release are available [here.](https://github.com/pyxem/pyxem/milestone/6?closed=1)

## General Development & simple bug fixes

- HyperSpy signal registration (introduced in 0.10.0) was overhauled to fix some errors and to use set_signal_type where possible #553 
- We adopted the black code style #560 #561 #566 
- get_diffraction_calibration and reference_circle was generalised to any detector size by removing hardcoded dimensions #558 #567 

## Virtual Imaging

- Virtual imaging code was generalized and moved to a new CommonDiffraction class for improved code re-use and the method was renamed to get_integrated_intensity #565 

## Peak Finding

- The performance of peak finders was significantly improved using numba #582 

## Diffraction Vectors

- An in_range argument was added to get_diffracting_pixels map and the test suite was improved #564 
- A bug for plotting vector matching results was fixed #586 

## Pattern Matching

- A new NormalizedCorrelation metric was added to the correlate method #545 
- A bug in get_nth_best_solution was fixed #575 

## Azimuthal2D Integration

- A PolarDiffraction2D class was introduced with a reproject_polar method #524 
- pyFAI Azimuthal2D Integration was introduced #574 

## Merlin/Medipix file reader

- The load_mib function was updated to enable alternative loading of very large datasets #549 #571 

## Angular Correlation

- Angular correlation from empyer was merged into pyxem #572

name: pyxem 0.10.1
body:
pyXem 0.10.1 is a patch of pyXem, an open-source Python library for crystallographic diffraction. This patch is designed to accommodate the newly release minor version of diffsims (v0.2.2), which adds significant improvements for the orientation mapping pipeline. A few other patch-level fixes are included.

Breaking Changes
-------------------------
* diffsims now needs to be in v0.2.2 (or potentially higher), installing the version will force this change. Behaviour of pyxem code is unchanged.

Bugfixes
------------
* A radian/degree bug in `CrystallographicMap` has been fixed (#528,#529)

Minor Changes
--------------------
* Assorted internal improvements (#532, #534, #535, #536)

name: pyxem 0.10.0
body:
pyXem 0.10.0 is the Q3 2019 minor release of pyXem, an open-source Python library for crystallographic diffraction.

In this release cycle we have added a significant amount of new functionality to the code, as summarized below. The API for prior functionality from v0.9.x has changed very minimally. Details of all development associated with this release are available [here.](https://github.com/pyxem/pyxem/milestone/5?closed=1)

## HyperSpy Extension & Lazy Signal Classes

- pyxem now registers as a hyperspy extension on installation.
- This means that all pyxem Signal and Component classes are recognised by hyperspy
- LazyDiffraction1D, LazyDiffraction2D, LazyElectronDiffraction1D and LazyElectronDiffraction2D classes have been added and can be used with lazy file loading for hyperspy supported file types.

## pyFAI Detector Definitions and Azimuthal Integration

- pyxem now depends on pyFAI from ESRF, Grenoble.
- New azimuthal integration using pyFAI has been added in Diffraction2D.get_azimthual_integral()
- Detector definitions in the pyFAI framework have been added to pyxem for a genereic_flat_detector, a 256x256 Medipix chip and a 515x515 (i.e. quad) Medipix chip.

## Analysis of Non-Crystals

- Pair Distribution Function calculation for every diffraction pattern in a scanned dataset is now supported. This includes numerous additional classes and methods.
- Fluctuation Microscopy is now supported.

## Diffraction Vector Analysis & Indexation

- New density based clustering has been added to the get_unique_vectors() method
- New methods filter_vectors_magnitudes() and filter_vectors_detector_edge() have been added to make it easy to exclude commonly problematic vectors.
- A new integrationGenerator to associated integrated intensity with indexed DiffractionVectors has been added.
- A new refine_best_orientation() method has been added to the VectorIndexationGenerator.

## Strain Mapping

- We have enhanced code underlying lattice fitting based strain mapping.
- The StrainMap class now had a change_basis() method to allow easy and reliable coordinate transformations.
- The existing cross-correlation method of peak refinement has been improved and a new method using a separate template for every disc implemented.
- Testing of the subpixel refinement methods has been overhauled and improved.

## Nanocrystal Segmentation

- Algorithms for correlating images and isolating diffraction associated with individual crystals have been added.
- New VDFSegment and LearningSegment classes have been added to support this nanocrystal segmentation

## Pattern Matching

- The algorithm for construction orientation lists for generating libraries of simulated patterns has been adjusted to provide a more generally correct answer at the expense of speed.
- Testing of the pattern matching methods have been overhauled and improved.

## Data Pre-processing

- New algorithms have been added to the center_direct_beam() method to offer greater flexibility
- A new function to help optimize background subtraction parameters has been added.
- Some "big data utils" have been added to support automated chunking of scanned diffraction data into sections that can be processed with restricted RAM.

## Merlin/Medipix file reader

- A new file reader for Merlin/Medipix detectors has been added
- This file reader supports all current data formats and detector sizes with lazy file loading

name: pyXem 0.9.2
body: pyXem 0.9.2 is a patch release of pyXem, an open-source Python library for crystallographic electron microscopy. It makes resolves some problems associated with numpy v1.17 Developer changes - This (and subsequent releases) now depend on `hyperspy >= 1.5.2` (#470 here and #471 on master) - We are no longer meaningfully constrained in our numpy version

name: pyXem 0.9.1
body: pyXem 0.9.1 is a patch release of pyXem, an open-source Python library for crystallographic electron microscopy. It makes some fixes some minor bugs to smooth usage as the 2019-2020 academic year begins. Fixes A minor import bug for loading mib files has been fixed (#467 with master version at #461) Developer changes This version is now locked to numpy 1.16.5 (#467 with master version at #464)

name: pyXem 0.9.0
body:
pyXem 0.9.0 is a minor release of pyXem, an open-source Python library for crystallographic diffraction microscopy, for workshops at Microscopy & Microanalysis 2019 and the European Crystallographic Meeting.

Details of all development associated with this release are available [here.](https://github.com/pyxem/pyxem/milestone/3?closed=1)

## API Change

- ElectronDiffraction --> ElectronDiffraction2D
- DiffractionProfile --> ElectronDiffraction1D
- pxm.load() is now only intended for files saved from pyxem
- pxm.load_hsyp(filename, assign_to='electron_diffraction2d') is the new syntax for using hyperspy to load files and assign them to the ElectronDiffraction2D class
- pxm.load_mib() is for mib files.
- All simulation code from pyxem-0.8.0 factored out to a new external package called diffsims - see: https://github.com/pyxem/diffsims This means that most Generator and Library classes from pyxem-0.8.0 should now be imported from diffsims

## New Features

- CalibrationGenerator includes methods for calibrating rotation between real and reciprocal space.
- New least squares lattice fitting method for strain mapping
- Radiation agnostic functionality was factored out to new  Diffraction1D and Diffraction2D classes
- LazyElectronDiffraction2D, LazyElectronDiffraction1D, LazyDiffraction1D and LazyDiffraction2D classes were added to provide out_of_memory processing.

## Enhancements

- Including exclude_border argument for peak finders
- Default values added to plot_diffraction_vectors method.

## Bug Fixes

- Gaussian SubpixelRefinement bug fixed
- Decomposition wrapper updated for correct class assignment.
- roi imported from hyperspy

name: pyXem 0.8.1
body: pyXem 0.8.1 is a patch release of pyXem, an open-source Python library for crystallographic electron microscopy. Details below: Additions: new keep_dtype option in .apply_affine_transform() (#411) Fixes: .apply_affine_transform() now accept Signal2D for D (#411) Developer Notes: dependency versions updated in conda-forge and setup.py (#410)

name: pyXem 0.8.0
body:
pyXem 0.8.0 is a minor release of pyXem, an open-source Python library for crystallographic electron microscopy, for an Electron Diffraction Workshop @ NTNU Norway on 15/16 May 2019 (https://www.ntnu.edu/physics/temgemini/diffraction2019).

Details of all development associated with this release are available [here.](https://github.com/pyxem/pyxem/milestone/1?closed=1)

## New Features

- CalibrationGenerator() class implemented

## Enhancements

- vector library generator re-written to change inner loop for numpy operations
- match_vector re-written to change inner loop for numpy operations
- peaks for vector matching enabled to be chosen based on angular distribution
- various minor improvements to vector matching methods

## Bug Fixes

- appveyor matplotlib backen set to "agg" to avoid test issue
- the load_mib function was corrected to treat the y-axis consistently
- bug in vector library found and corrected in updates
- rotation direction returned by vector matching made consistent with template matching and as Euler angles in degrees

## Documentation

- install instructions updated for conda-forge / pypi
- website moved to a separate repo so that it is no longer distributed with the code.
- website relocated to www.pyxem.org

name: pyXem 0.7.1
body: pyXem is a library for crystallographic electron microscopy in python. This minor release makes various small changes associated with distribution and packaging.

name: pyXem 0.7
body:
pyXem 0.7 is the first full release of pyXem, which is a an open-source Python library for crystallographic electron microscopy.

Details of all development associated with this release are available [here.](https://github.com/pyxem/pyxem/milestone/2?closed=1)

## New Features

- VDFGenerator() class implemented
- Vector based methods added to IndexationGenerator()
- Vector based strain mapping methods implemented
- SubPixelRefinementGenerator() for sub-pixel peak finding implemented
- StructureLibraryGenerator() to create StructureLibrary() objects including crystallography
- Calibration and virtual imaging utility functions added to ElectronDiffractionProfile class

## Enhancements

- apply_affine_transformation refactored to increase speed significantly
- template matching code rewritten in vectorised form to increase speed
- calculation of structure factors in kinematical simulations rewritten in vectorized form to increase speed
- masking added to azimuthal integration function
- axes are now transferred correctly between objects

## Bug Fixes

- A matrix transpose issue in obtaining strain maps was corrected

## For Developers

- Test coverage reached 100% code coverage
- Tests packaged
- Continuous integration of code on linux, windows, and mac with python 3.6 and python 3.7
- Documentation of important coordinate and crystallographic conventions
- zenodo DOI created
- code uploaded to pypi
- conda-forge recipe created

name: pyXem 0.6
body: This release is the first to depend fully on diffpy for structure manipulations. Orientation and strain mapping implementations for crystalline specimens are working in the original architecture where orientation mapping is achieved only by template matching.

name: pyXem 0.5.1
body: This release is the final one to depend on pymatgen and is provided for convenience. Future code replaced pymatgen's functionality with diffpy and we recommend users move over to those releases as soon as is feasible.

name: pyXem 0.5
body: This release contains everything as of 24/06/2018. At this time we decided to cut some of the fat off the code base. So that (almost) all functionality is available somewhere, a formal "0.5" was created.
